The Mini Zorcher from Chex Quest!

Chex Quest was a mod of the '90s video game Doom, which was given out for free in boxes of Chex cereal. Instead of guns, you would use a "Zorcher" to keep slime monsters from getting your cereal soggy. It was a...weird time for video games.

This is the 'Mini Zorcher', which acts like the pistol from Doom.

The body prints standing up with no support, but the zappers require support when printing upright.

Just print everything out and put it together!

title: Pneumatic Solenoid Bracket for Robotics (Festo VUVG-L10-B52-T-M7)

description.text:
This is a basic bracket for a common pneumatic solenoid made by Festo that is used in FIRST Robotics builds and other machines. The bracket allows the solenoid to be easily and quickly removed for tweaking and maintenance without tools. The brackets also make great place holders during a build so the real solenoids don't get beat up while you are running lines and wires. It also makes it easier to share solenoids among several robots since they are pretty pricey.

Updated to V4: I reduced the size of the side tabs to clear another 1mm of space around the wire plugs so the release tab is easier to get to. I also increased the clearance in the wire guides so thicker wires can be stowed behind the towers. That is meant to eliminate strain from he plug itself in the event the wires are staged or otherwise pulled. If you run the wire through the guide before plugging in the connector it will all sure up nicely.

Printer:

Custom Printer running SMoothieware

Resolution:

Variable .15-.3

Infill:

25% Honeycomb

Notes:

I printed this model with Hatchbox PETG at 250C. It's designed to be a tight fit that relies on the PETG to give a bit during instal and removal of the solenoid. There is some minor play once the valve is seated in the bracket but it is very secure. I set the bottom of the bracket to print at .3mm and then switched to .15 for the towers to increase their strength. For setup in Slic3r, that means 0-4.8mm set at .03 and 5.0-22.1 at .15mm in the layer height table. Slic3r also allowed me to print the bracket body with 2 shells but filled in the towers so they printed solid. My final print looks a little sloppy because I don't have the settings for the PETG dialed in just right but I was more focused on fit and function over finish on this piece so I didn't spend time tuning it for anything but strength.

I suspect it could be just as good if printed in TPU with enough shells/walls but it probably won't work well with normal PLA since the side tabs won't won't be able to flex enough to fit the part in without breaking.

description.text:
I needed laser engraver, but didn't wanna buy one to save space in my rental apartment. Instead I've got a 5W solid state laser module and installed it on my Delta Printer. Since my delta printer using magnetic joints - I can swap between laser head and 3D printer head in a matter of seconds. This mount with a set of 6 countersunk magnets replaces standard K800 magnetic effector (like the red one on picture).

Magnets (12 mm countersunk)

https://www.ebay.com/itm/122110638994

Laser module 2.5W

Best value for the money!
https://www.ebay.com/itm/Focusable-High-Power-2-5W-450nm-Blue-Laser-Module-TTL-12V-Carving-free-Goggles-H-/152845584678?_trksid=p2385738.m4383.l4275.c10

Laser module 5W

Faster and cleaner cuts of thicker materials!
https://www.ebay.com/itm/5W-Laser-Head-Engraving-Module-Wood-Marking-Wood-Cutting-For-Engraver-W-TTL/323002592505

TLL input is a must have

Otherwise it will be harder to control laser exposure. Without TTL input you can only vary the speed of laser trajectory. Which might be not enough for some some scenarios and hard to tune to the required level. Connecting TTL input to colling FAN output MOSFET you can control laser power setting fan speed (M106 Sxxx and M107 G-code commands). Please refer to details on this page: https://electronics.stackexchange.com/questions/321987/convert-12vdc-fan-controller-output-to-ttl-signal-of-laser

And DON'T FORGET protection glasses

For a blue laser you need green color
https://www.ebay.com/itm/Alternative-Laser-Eye-Protection-Safety-Glasses-Goggles-For-Various-lasers-1pc

Applications

If you do home PCB DIY - the laser engraver is absolutely must have thing for you. Because it helps to accomplish different stages of PCB manufacturing:

  • At low power setting you may use blue laser to expose copper layer pattern directly to photo-resist film applied to copper clad. No need to print templates on clear plastic projector film and then struggle with variability of UV lamp distance and time of exposure. I also had to print two mirrored templates and precisely align them together, since having single layer of ink-jet ink were not enough to properly block UV light. Exposing photo-resist dirreclty with with laser can give you resolution of 1/10 of mm (llokup RasterToGCode Inkscape plugin https://github.com/305engineering/Inkscape) This accuracy is less than what I can obtain using ink-jet printed templates but more than enough for most of prototyping projects. Though my last prototypes are so complex and have so many drills that I do prefer to order boards on fab (PCBWay or OSHPark).

  • If you still don't wanna hustle with laminating photo-resist film to your copper clad and its development in caustic soda solution - you may skip these going slightly dirtier way, but still using a laser. Just spray paint your PCB with black acrylic paint and then burn the negative pattern with a laser at high-power setting. Vaporizing the acrylic paint is less precise than exposing photo-resist at low power, but for the sake of simplicity you may trade off the accuracy.

  • 2..5W laser can cut plastic films that may be used as SMD-stencils to apply solder paste on PCB pads. To get clean cuts without curling of plastic drop a white paper sheet on top of the plastic film and spray it with water. Wait for paper to soaked and swipe-off the excess water with a credit card (yeah, sorry, you need a credit card here). Water-soaked sheet of paper on top cools down the plastic edge immediately after laser slit through. It also helps to absorb laser energy when cutting clear plastic films. Without paper it almost impossible to cut clear plastic film, yellowish kapton however absorbs laser light quite effectively and burns fast, still need watered paper to prevent excessive curling on cut edges.

  • Finally - 2..5W laser can cut colored acrylic and plywood. It can't do clear plexiglas for the very same reason of energy absorption vs its dissipation ratio. On a picture - I've got a solder-paste applicator setup for one of my PCBs. SMD-stencil for solder paste was cut out of clear plastic film used for projectors. A jig to hold custom-shaped PCB was cut out of 1/16" black non-transparent acrylic sheet (the same thickness as of PCB). Absolute satisfaction of using this (did like 150 boards in few hours).

https://youtu.be/ADJc9kbJicc

Printer:

FlSun Kossel Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25 .. 50

Notes:

ABS plastic is recommended from durability standpoint. In case laser cooling fan malfunction PLA may overheat and melt, however it is more likely that the laser will die before that happen.

Scale the part accordingly to the shrinkage factor of your plastic when it cools down.
Press-fit or glue countersunk magnets into the part.

author: Hassi

description.text:
The STL files above are printable parts that successfully when put together create a full model of an animal cell . Suitable for any biology , anatomy or aquatic science class to teach students about parts of a cell. Some key things to remember for certain parts are :

Vacoule : Print with the Rectangle hole facing up .
SmoothER : Print with the Rectangle piece facing up on the build plate .
RER : Print with the Rectangle piece facing up on the build plate .
Nucleus : Print with small half sphere facing down on the build plate and add support
Mitochondria : Print with curvy line facing up and rectangle hole facing down on build plate .
Lysosome and peroxisome: Print with circle base facing up and also print with a Brim otherwise part won't print.
Golgi : Print flat with square peg on object facing up .
Centriole: Print cylindrical tubes facing up and not sideways . Also print with a brim for stabilization and so it doesn't break.
The Bases : The base parts , the only thing to remember when printing is to have the side without the pegs and hole facing hup and the side of the part with no pegs and holes face down on build plate .

Buy magnets to hot glue on parts

description.text:
This is a 3d printable Snowboard Vise.
Store prices were ridiculous so I have designed my own.
Vise is very simple to enable fast printing & low resolution.

You will need:
-large printbed 20x25 cm
-threaded bolt 10mm
-screw 17mm (optional, works without it, but once PLA thread wears out you can insert the screw-> see picture)

Ball & plate are optional, I've added them to reduce damage to the table.
I have additionally added a very thin layer of silicone at top (to improve snowboard hold) and at bottom (touching table) so less tension is needed.

Happy waxing & sharpening of the board!!!

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.6 / .2

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Vise printed at .5 and 75mm, which is Max speed for my printer (underextrusion started to show), you can try even faster.

Ball tip & plate printed at .2 for precision.

comments.text:
Hi, thanks for sharing this design.
I have one question: how do you secure the board to this vise?
insert the edge into the slot at the top?(one vertical and one 45 degrees?)
comments.author: hueyhy

comments.text:
Hi,
The vise has three uses:
1)Waxing, where you lay snowboard upside down on top. This is where most grip is needed especially when scraping off wax. Please consider silicone finishing your vise.
2)90 degree sharpening, where you just slide it in straight. There is very low friction when sharpening so board should stay in place. If you want better grip, consider adding silicone finishing to bottom of the slot.
3)45 degree sharpening, where you slide it in at an angle. Here you should have better hold than 90 degree because the board is wedged. You can also add silicone finishing if you want, but is shouldn't be needed.

If ever there was proof of the usefulness of the 3D printer, this is it!

Every day, we feed our chickens tomato and cucumber out of 2 Lurpack butter tubs, but the addition of 4 more chickens, meant we needed a third tub, but I only have 2 hands.

I'm happy, the chickens are happy and the eggs taste great.

This is a simple Scan Helper for Kinect V2 (Xbox One).
With the 3D Scanner App from Microsoft you can scan free hand and also with turntable but both is not optimal. A lot of objects have not enough reference points to detect correct position and also up and down scanning is hard to figure out. Free hand scanning is too imprecise and causes issues when coming too close or too far.

With this little helper you can place an object on a fixed platform and you move the Kinect around with exact same distance and viewing angle. This makes scans much better. It adds the precision of platform scan while the scanner software can still use the background as movement reference. Just use a metal pipe as a shaft that is long enough. You can then slide the Kinect on it to get good distance. Start scanning and move the Kinect around in a perfect Sphere shape to get all sides of the object.

My sample scans are made with very bad light conditions and my cables are still too short (and my room too small g) but the results are better then every scan before.

I also uploaded step files, so you can edit the sketches and make your own helper with correct sizes for your used pipe.

title: Full Size Optimus Prime Cos-Play Costume

description.text:
Sorry for not posting sooner but i wanted to make this a big surprise.
This Print is based off a Toy.
The first Few Pictures are of the Toy so i could get some measurements for the Full Size Costume.
This is my Full Size 6 foot tall Optimus Prime Costume for the next Comic-Con event.
please expect to spend at least 300 to 400 hours printing this Costume. an about at least ten rolls of filament.
Most parts are .4mm think layer down to .2mm layer depending on part and Support.
You will have to adjust your printer according to your finish. This was done on Both my CoreXY Printers and my extra Larger Delta Printer.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2731724
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2718545
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2414471
And i adjusted the Z Axis down to 340mm per step to make the shell stronger but just a little shorter since this will be a costume and will have to endure 20 hours of wearing it.
I only started printing this Costume less then 2 weeks ago, so it is a Print In Progress.

Parts will be updated and removed as it progresses to the finish product, so expect parts to be added and removed.

This will be my biggest 3d build up to date, my last 3d Build was my Dalek.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2576488
and even thou i only printed from the mid section up.

All the parts listed here were printed hollow with a 2mm thick shell. The original pieces came from a 3d Printed Optimus Prime Toy I found on line and enlarged to 6 feet tall then hollowed out.

Some parts are from that original toy but then some parts I changed to make the costume look like a newer Optimus Prime.
The original Optimus Prime which this costume is based off of is located here.
https://cults3d.com/en/3d-model/art/optimus-prime

This is still a work in Progress, I've just got the Lower Legs and a few Garments to print, but i should be done in the next month.

You will need a Larger Printer to print these parts.
Each part will take anywhere from 4 hours to print up to 20 hours to print.
You can print these part on smaller Printers but expect to spend double the time printing this.

I hope you enjoy this, as i had plenty of headaches along the way, but it is coming along just fine.
Included in this is the Full Size Optimus Prime with 2 different heads, 3 different Swords, 2 different Gas tanks, 2 different Shoulders, And Optimus Primers Gen 1 Blaster and other parts from other Prime version that i though would look nice in full size.
Every part in this is for a full size 6 foot tall Costume, Every piece has been split in 2 or 4 or even 8 parts so it can be printed on my extra large Printers. If you plan on printing these parts on a smaller printer then what i have listed in this description then you will have to split the pieces even smaller.

3-2-2018: I've just uploaded a Brand New Sword Of Judgment. I hope you like it. It was the best i can do with the software i had on hand. Expect this sword to be updated as i get into better detail on the sword and include Cybertonium Language embossed on the sword.
https://tfsource.com/sword-of-judgement/

-4: Paused at layer 31, filament changed to wood filament.

description.text:
This is a fidget spinner that uses pennies for weights in the arms of the spinner. The print is paused to insert the pennies and then they're sealed in with the subsequent layers.

There are 6 variants of the model included. Three of the variants are designed for insertion of a 608 bearing in the center. The other three have a bearing outer ring at the center and are designed for insertion of 4.5 mm steel BBs and a printed inner bearing ring and a printed bearing BB spacer.

4.68 mm penny cavity - sized to fit 3 Canadian pennies minted in 2000 or later, pause it at height greater than 5.84 mm
4.92 mm penny cavity - sized to fit 3 Canadian pennies minted in 1979 or earlier, pause it at height greater than 5.96 mm
6.00 mm penny cavity - sized to fit 4 Canadian pennies minted in 2000 or later, pause it at height greater than 6.5 mm

The other three variants are the same as above, but with the built-in bearing outer ring. They spin quite well - as long as the models with a $1.80 steel bearing inserted, but they're not as smooth spinning so they rattle and shake a tiny bit and aren't silent like the steel bearings. I print the inner bearing ring and spacer at 100% infill for maximum strength. If you're printing any of these models, you may have to do a bit of post-print cleanup. All of mine had a tiny bump on the bottom layer of the bearing parts, which I filed down. You'll probably have to scale the finger pads to 97% or 96% to fit snuggly into the printed bearings. I print mine with 4 perimeter shells so that the twisted pin parts are solid. I put a tiny dab of SuperLube Synthetic Grease on each BB before I insert the finger pads into the bearing.

American pennies are the same diameter, so they can be used as well.

The best fidget spinner, giving the most weight, will be one that uses 1979 or earlier pennies since they weigh 3.24 grams each, compared to 2.35 grams for the newer pennies. The next best would be one that has 4 pennies in each arm. Since the older pennies are also thicker (1.53 mm) than the newer pennies (1.43 mm), they won't fit so you must use newer pennies. Depending on your printer and filament quality, the layer printed on top of the pennies might be messy and with the 4 penny model there is little room for the subsequent layers to cover the flaws, so the top surface may have some slight ripples. If you want a completely smooth top surface, you might need to print one of the 3 penny models. In the first photo there is a three penny model on the left, and a four penny model on the right where you can see the slight rippling I was getting with the 4 penny model.

The prints won't tolerate any warping or else the pennies might not fit in. The cooling fan is definitely needed for the layer printed on top of the pennies since it's essentially bridging at that point. I print mine with the fan off for the first layer and on for the rest of the print.

My printer doesn't support pausing via the G code and must be manually paused, so I add a tiny tab at the front of the print so that I know when to pause the printer. I've included the correctly positioned tab file for all three variants of the model. If you use the tab files, you may want to move them so they're poking out a bit more, since they're barely visible where I have them positioned. When the perimeters have been printed and the infill starts for the tab layer, I immediately pause the print and insert the pennies.

This is a remix of Tri Fidget Spinner Toy by 2ROBOTGUY. I scaled the model up to 101% in X and Y so that the bearing fits in easily, but still snug. I then added to each arm some hollow cylinders that I created in OpenSCAD. The bearing parts are a remix of 608 bearing (4.5mm steel BB's) by SiberK. The models were designed to be printed with a first layer height of 0.2 mm and 0.12 mm for the other layers. I'm not sure how important the layer heights are, but that's what I used for all my prints.

Tip: Use 3M General Purpose Masking Tape High Adhesion for maximum adhesion and to eliminate warping. I had always been printing on 3M Scotch-Blue Painters Tape, but it doesn't really stick that well to the built plate and the spinner arms tended to lift ever so slightly. So I tried the general purpose tape and it works great! The prints stick to it really well, and it sticks to the build plate really well. Unlike the blue tape which I would leave on the build plate and would be used for dozens of prints, the general purpose tape is single use only. So instead of covering the whole build plate with the blue tape I cover only the area needed with the beige tape.

FlashForge Creator Pro

Closure for drill box or similar. A colleague told me that he needed a closure for the drill box, come on, I think he later told me it was for a box of a tile cutter. So I have put an inner part with springs that exert a pressure so that it is well crimped and even when the tab of the counterpart is worn does not open with time. title: Geeetech G2S/G2S Pro Acrylic Parts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
What with trying to design mods for my printer, I figured having a virtual model would be handy and... just got a bit carried away.
As I've seen some complaining about not being able to get plans for the acrylic parts in case of breakage, I thought I'd upload my copies here.

Quick caveats; as the manufacturing process and design appears to change every so often, I'd check the parts against yours before printing or cutting anything. Mine, for example, uses the slim LCD mounts, one of which I snapped and started this whole ball rolling...
In addition, whilst I'm measuring most of these with digital calipers good to .01mm, human error comes into play, and the parts aren't the most... consistent... to begin with.
In some places I've taken averages for dimensions, in some (where it's perilously close to a round number), I've set the dimension as to what I believe the original intent was to be.

One part is definitely out; the non-mounting detail for the "Fan Mount - RK-07" is basically an approximation because my version's buried in my printer, and I'm not about to yank the bed to bits to measure something that's irrelevant. All the actual holes and pins should be in the right place.
In addition, this has slightly different spacings (they're out by less than a mm, IIRC) for the LCD mounts on the baseplate and the actual LCD panel. This is actually as measured. Don't ask me, I didn't cut it. :D

If anyone's doing version tracking, this particular set/design of cut parts was purchased March 2017 from their UK warehouse. Allegedly. There are probably many other weird and wonderful versions. This is for the dual-material G2S Pro; although there was some part reuse I suspect some bits got juggled around over time.

(In case you were wondering, the lead image is a render of the current state of my model. I've taken to throwing the mods on it as I build them, and at some point if they prove reliable, I'll upload most of them here.)

Edit:
I've now had replacement plates 1 & 2 cut from those patterns and have been able to dismember my printer properly to check the baseplate.
The fan mount is now an appropriate profile, instead of a "it'll hold things in the right place" guess.
Screw holes on the top plate for the spool mounting panels were placed wrong due to bad maths, and have been corrected.
The fan mount, motherboard, and cable-tie holes on the side of the baseplate have been properly measured and relocated, instead of estimated positions based on other features, originally. The fillet on the hole for the bed heater wiring has been lessened.

remixed_from.author: Kommander92
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 X-belt tensioner for GT2 pulley

title: Anet A8 X-belt tensioner for GT2 pulley

description.text:
This is a remix of Kommander92's thing. The "fork" on the original design had ~3mm of vertical play when used with the stock anet a8 x-idler block (white injection molded part, purchased early 2018). The slop allows the pulley to move up/down a ton on the new idler blocks. I widened the distance between the prongs to fit the stock idler housing and remove most of this slop. I presume the original "thin fork" design was meant to fit printed idler blocks, which probably have a smaller opening. So this remix may not fit printed idler blocks (I have no printed idler blocks to check this... will edit some info if someone discovers this is the case).

Also the 16T GT2 toothed idler I purchased online was 8.5mm wide overall. The flat wall opening on Kommander92's version is 10mm wide. Presumably the extra room was there to fit washers on either side. Standard 3mm washers will rub on the bearing dust shields (no bueno). So I moved both shaft holes inwards 0.75mm. This transformed the walls where the pulley goes into shallow cones, which keep the bearing well centered without rubbing on the dust shields (no washers required).

I printed this in PLA and it fits well. Other x-tensioner things seem to be done with 20% infill, but on a critical structural component like this I feel 40% is a better choice.

author: truglodite

description.text: TPU protective case for Foxeer Box camera.
I didn't find that the original model was capable of tightening, so I flipped the nut to the inside and it works great.

Keep in mind that this is a major work in progress but, many have asked for my .stls so here they are! This frame support 20mm stacks using 11xx motors, and uses a <16mm wide battery strap, designed around ~29mm wide batteries. This setup mounts the Split Mini camera off the top of the stack, and covers the split mini circuit boards. You can secure the camera holder to the top of the stack using M2X4 screws, or M2x10 screws if you're using a VTX03 and want to use the stack topper I made for it! The bottom screws that thread into the stack are M2x12. The electronics stack I'm using is an Eachine Minicube stack with a lemonRX sandwiched in the middle, although you should be able to use any 20x20 stack you like!

Note that you can't use Runcam's SD card securing thing with this design, yet anyway. Did I mention it's a work in progress? :)

Another note: I've been scaling the frame up to 4.8mm thickness, at 125% scale on Z and 100/100 for x/y. It's 3.8mm by default but I like the extra beefiness, an optional step but it lets you use M2X7 screws for your motors which I seem to have collected dozens of.

comments.text: Cool design - any specific reason why the motor mounting holes are not aligned so that you can run the cables along the frame instead of through the air?

I have prop guards that I sometimes like to run on this thing that require the motors to be angled as they are, but when not running prop guards it would definitely be advantageous to have the motor wires in line with the frame, I'll update this when I get around to it!

title: Prusa MK3 Einsey Raspberry Pi Zero Octopi Case Remix

description.text:
Please be sure to get all the info on this design from the original source "MoonDoggy."

This is a remix of a great design by MoonDoggy. There was one flaw in the design where the strain relief filament for the heated bed wires going into the Einsy enclosure didn't have a tube/tunnel to hold the filament... without it... the filament wire will move loose inside the case. Prusa restrained the filament wire for a reason. I imagine that is was because the filament wire would me moving inside the case and messing with the internal wiring. When you print this design please note the tiny vertical tube/tunnel on the wall of the main case where the heated bed wires enter the Einsy case. The black filament wire goes in that little tunnel to keep the wire from moving around inside the case.

Please be sure to get all the info on this design from the original source "MoonDoggy."

title: Samsung Gear VR USB Slave Adapter

description.text:
Since the Samsung Gear VR 2016 disables USB slave mode once connected I decided to make a USB adaptor that would allow me to tether my phone to my PC and still use the gear vr.

I use the cable for tethered streaming of Steam VR to my phone.

This model is heavily based on Zarbuta's original adaptor (see attribution) and the original gear vr connector.

I've created several prototypes which is in the history of the fusion 360 file. This final version isn't perfect but it's good enough so here are the files for others to improve on.

Make sure to read the post-printing note on the wings and fitting the back plate cover as some minor modification is required.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

Printed this on my cheap Balco printer with the included mats, using Simplify3d and the default High PLA preset. In the past I'd tune the process settings to get the best quality at the sacrifice of speed but in reality aesthetics don't really matter for this little project so I stuck with defaults. The only thing I changed was the top layer count to 8 to avoid pillowing.

I found the best way to print this so the internals fit cleanly and the adapter slides into the gear vr and the switch properly fastens was to print the adapter facing down so the (USB port is pointing down). I printed the switch with the switch button facing up. I printed the back plate with the larger external side facing down.

I generated supports and added some additional support for the hole cutouts. There was a little bit of work cleanly removing all the support, especially in the side tracks. I used a small precision flat-head screw driver and tweezers.

Modification 1

Minor oversight in the length of the switch guiding wings. You will need to trim them down in either the file or physically in order to fit the switch in. I trimmed mine down so about 1mm per side remained.

Modification 2 (optional)

If I had more time I'd extend elongate the adapter by 1 - 1.5mm to allow the usb connector more room when putting the back plate on. If you look at the photo you'll see the connector pushing against the back plate.

Modification 3 (optional)

To make this printed model look better and resemble the original Samsung adaptor a little more, I'd create an inner face plate where the phone rests on the adaptor. This would form a u-shape which you'd print without much support (if any). You could then glue it to the adaptor.

Soldering the wires

I TAKE NO RESPONSIBILITY FOR ANY ISSUES FOLLOWING THIS GUIDE! USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!

Make absolutely sure you don't wire the vcc and ground incorrectly!!!

I threaded the USB cable through the side hole in the adaptor first. I then placed a salvaged male micro USB connector inside the adaptor.

To solder the wires I found it easier to use tweezers and wedged the wires under the contact pads so they were held in place while I added solder to them. I also used a solder flux pen to help the solder adhere better (best invention!).

I used a bit of hot glue to insulate the solder wires from each other and some around the base of the usb connector to hold it in place.

I used the 4 screws that came with the original samsung gear vr adapter to fasten the backplate cover to the adapter. It was a really tight fit.
Used Autodesk Fusion 360 Ultimate and a pair of digital calipers.

description.text:
EDIT: The entire file I have updated. A single unit will fit on the gangway, and one will fit at the top of the platform. I have split it into 3 parts. One of the lower bunker portion, which prints out fine with its attached ladder, the second part is the attachment point for hooking the ladder to the bunker, this should allow for magnet modification or other things. The third is the large ladder and platform.

Edit: I have printed the part as pictured with no support - just a quick test to get a judge of size. the ladder and handrails came out well even with no support, so if you print this with the support it should come out perfect. I am thinking of sizing it up slightly. It will fit about 3 models inside (intended to be a small building) . The ladder and gangway are an appropriate size for the model itself, but you can not position a model with its base on the gangway, it is too narrow. I think I should widen it so you can sit a model there at least for posing purposes. I may just increase the size of the whole structure in general to allow a model to be placed on the gangway and upper loading platform.

This is a thought I had for an AT-ST loading station for star wars legion, but a simple one with a protective wall/bunker at the base. I have not printed it yet, and hoping to get more information on the At-ST height, so I have made the upper ladder and platform a second file that could be adjusted height-wise. This is based off me measuring screen shots against figures, and guessing it's a little more than 5.5" high. Feel free to make adjustments to that so it actually fits, or this idea may be better off made when the game actually comes out.

I may need to split the ladders and platforms further depending on how it prints, and will update it.

Let me know if you have any info on how tall that thing actually is.

Bed temp: layer 1 to 5 at 90C rest at 80C
Fan on after 10 layers
Skirt layers 2, outlines 10 to prevent warping

You will need to use o-rings on the printed caps, which provide a nice seal. Specifically, you will need 1 or 2 (I use 2) of the following for each cap:
1 1/16" OD x 15/16" ID x 1/16"

Sorry if o-rings are only available in metric sizes in your locale: I don't know what the appropriate substitute would be. If you want to leave a comment letting me know what works for you, I'll be happy to update the description.

I'm considering supergluing the o-rings to the caps, as it's possible for them to pop off if you're not careful. I may provide an updated cap design to prevent this if superglue proves ineffective.

The "E" on the canister can be used to indicate that a given roll has been exposed. If the pointer on the cap points to the "E" side of the canister, the film is exposed. (Or you can simply ignore this.)

title: Tronxy BootLoader Install & Software Update Guide

description.text:
I bought a TRONXY X5S in December of 2017. I knew it would need updates and changes so I expected to have to upload new MARLIN code into the machine. Wizard has posted a working version of Marlin 1.1.8 setup for the X5S (THANKS!!!!) The link to this work is found at: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738690

As suggested as a problem in Wizard's post, I too found out that my X5S unit did not have a bootloader installed. This meant that I could not "talk to the X5S" from the Arduino IDE; that is, it was NOT ready to accept new programs or updates..

After doing much web research, I figured out that I needed to have an ISP (In-System-Programmer) with which to burn the bootloader. This is done using the PROGRAM HEADER on the Printer Control Board (AKA the MELZI board) and NOT the normal printer USB connection.

A search of eBay revealed many inexpensive ISP programmers but none seemed to be compatible with the Atmel 1284P.

Fortunately, almost any 5 volt Arduino board can be made into an ISP. In the attached PDF file, you will find my notes on how I on built an ISP out of a NANO V3 board. (Use the WEB for to find the details for using an UNO or MEGA, or what ever 5V ATMEL board you may have on hand). These notes show the steps needed to build the ISP, load it with ISP code, and then use it to install the bootloader into a Melzi board. I also cover uploading new Marlin code into your X5S/Melzi board.

Unfortunately, this is a lot of screwing around to get going. However, the good news is that you will only need to burn the bootloader into your printer control board ONCE. That is, once the bootloader is present on the MELZI, you can use the Arduino IDE directly (through the normal USB connector between your PC and your printer) for all future uploads and updates of the MARLIN code into your printer.

===============CAUTIONS=================

  1. You must use great care building and connecting the ISP to your MELZI board. An error in wiring or interconnect between your ISP and your MELZI board may permanently damage your X5S MELZI board, the ISP you've built, and/or your PC!!!

  2. You must compile and install a special ISP program onto your Arduino NANO (or UNO, or Mega, or...) BEFORE you can use it to load the bootloader into your MELZI.

  3. You must have the SANGUINO support files installed into your Arduino IDE or you won't be able to compile code for the X5S and then load the code into your MELZ board.

  4. TAKE CARE: Once you use the ISP to install the bootloader onto your MELZI, your printer will CEASE TO FUNCTION as it had from the factory. A new version of MARLIN must be loaded (using the Arduion IDE) before your printer will come back to life.

  5. You must have new Marlin code and a valid X5S Configuration.h file ready to go in your Arduino IDE. Make sure it compiles without errors before going on. Note that without a valid Configuration.h file loaded with all of the important X5S settings, the Marlin code you load WILL NOT WORK. See Wizard link above for a working X5S code and Configuration.h file set to use as a starting point.

  6. If any of the above items scare you, do more research and/or get the help of a friend that has been through this process before.

Although I have succeeded installing the bootloader and getting my X5S updated, I am NOT an expert and my notes may not cover everything you may need. They do represent the detailed steps I worked up based on my web searches and they worked for me. I am posting them with the idea that they may help others as well.

Take care, go slow, and best of luck!.

remixed_from.title: Hypercube Evolution Enclosed Y End Stop Two parts

description.text:
WARNING: These lasers are not toys and they will hurt you! Make sure you wear eye protection when using them! PLEASE read this for more information.

Update 2/28/2018
I have a decent cable management system in place now. I'm using https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11978 for a cable chain on the Y-axis and using just a cable loom. I uploaded a new Y endcap and two loops for the cable loom. the Y endcap needs 3 brass inserts. Pictures will be uploaded later today.

Update 2/25/2018
I added an enclosure, but I'm still working on cutting the press board that I'm using for the "laser proof window" with an OD 3. I created 4 L/U channels that I solvent welded to the corner pieces. This allows me to just slide in the sides and remove them at any time, in case I need to cut or engrave something bigger. The top will just sit on top of the corner pieces and be held in place by the sides that I cut a little longer.

I also really need to start working on cable management. The cable loom was dragging and cut by the laser. I caught it in time before the cables were cut. In the printer configuration I generally have enough "wasted space" in the back for the drag chain to bend. However, without a Z-axis you can use the entire Y travel, so I need to figure something else out. Without a case the choice would be easy. My current thought is to have a cable chain for Y and then a spiral wrap for the X with a loop/holder on the X-carriage and the left Y-carriage. If you have any ideas please post it in the comments. Thanks!

This is a 5/8" or 16mm Tube CORE-XY frame concept. Some parts are based on Scott_3d's excellent Hypercube Evolution.

The project started with a impulse purchase of a 2.5W laser. I then went through my leftover bin and found that I had many key components to build the 3dp burner/engraver. Long story short I printed the parts and then decided I really wanted to stick with the core-xy concept. I had some 5/8" aluminum tubes laying around and decided to use them as a frame vs. the expensive extrusions.

So here is my rendition of a Tube Cube HEVO Engraver. Wait! Is this not then a 3d printer? I guess you could make it into one by adding a z-axis.....

BOM:

  • 5/8" or 16mm tubing aluminum ( probably could use steel too)
    Y-axis 500 mm = 400mm print area
    X-axis 440 mm = 300mm print area
    Z-axis 220 mm
  • 4 x 8mm linear rails
    Y-axis 500 mm
    X-axis 460 mm
  • 8 x 8mm linear bearings
  • 1 x RAMPS 1.4
  • 1 x Arduino Mega
  • 2 x Stepper drivers
  • 2 x Stepper motors
  • 1 x Power supply
  • 100 x brass 3mm inserts
  • bunch of screws (some sheet metal, nuts and bolts, etc.)
  • number 10 x 3" screw with 4 nuts for the z adjustment
  • 6 x tooth pulleys T20
  • 2 x smooth pulleys T20
  • Some PLA

BONUS:

  • Added my other corner piece that will allow you pass the vertical tubes through it. will come in in handy if you want to build a dual z-axis tube cube. It was not needed for the engraver version. (Lightweight_midpiece)

Printer:

Hypercube Evolution

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

octet

Notes:

I printed them all without supports.... except the corner pieces for the housing

I was surprised to find that there was not a nice slew drive design on Thingiverse so I made one. It's completely* parametric so you can integrate it into your projects. It's perfect for moving a large load around with a deep reduction ratio. A NEMA 17 stepper should generate significant torque using this. It uses 6mm BBs for rolling elements

The STL files are for a randomly chosen 100mm gear. You can adjust this for your own needs. Change the gear ratio (This will require tweaking my gear tooth profiling).

*Parametric but you might need to tune it a little.

PLEASE REMIX. I'd love to see this get more advanced features like an hourglass worm.

Just watched Maker'sMuse ImpossibleDovetail video and figured I'd see what I could do as a Tinkercad design. Did not implement the 'lock' concept of his last idea, but did implement a "box" idea. Keep in mind that for the box to work, what is in the box has to fit within the void of the bottom part.

Feel free to modify within Tinkercad, it should be a public design. If you're looking for a different box idea for giving your partner a ring in as part of your proposal, this might work. Or put in a pair of tickets to a movie, or dinner, or a massage for her feet, or something.

I did try to provide clearance for the parts to slide past each other, yet be tight enough that the shouldn't fall apart. I may have to tweak that after I've got a functioning printer again. (perhaps later this week.)

Recommend either printing twice in different colors, then assembling two contrasting boxes and share the one you think works best, or go to the Tinkercad view and download each piece as a separate printable file and print in just the colors you like for that part.

Remember to scale each part the same if you want a larger or smaller box for some reason.

title: Mini-Lathe adjustable carriage stop and indicator holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Another take on a 7X mini-lathe carriage stop. Inserts are used to switch between using it as a depth stop and indicator holder. There's a 10tpi LH screw and graduated knob for adjusting the stop. The indicator holder is sized for the 2" HF dial indicator.

The knob is printed separate from the bearing. The bearing and lock collar are printed in place and twisted loose after printing. I printed mine at .1mm layer height and had no problem rotating them loose.

I made printable versions of the fasteners, but since I'm not too sure of the longevity of plastic threads that will probably be cinched down very firmly, I've also included knurled caps for standard 3/8-16 UNC and 1/4-20 UNC bolts.

After I was happy with their orientation, I exported to STL and used Blender to smooth out the junctions and adjust the curvature to make it more organic looking, then exported it to rawtentacle.stl.

title: Fox and Hounds Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fox and Hounds is played on a chess board or checkers board sized 8x8. 4 similar colored pawns or checkers as hounds and a single pawn or checker in other color as a fox.

Hounds are placed onto fields b8, d8, f8, and h8. Fox starts set onto e1. Fox moves first.

Hounds hunting the fox. The fox moves diagonally one field range forward or backward onto an empty adjacent square per turn. Hounds can only move diagonally one field forward (towards row 1) onto an empty adjacent square.

Since only diagonal moves are allowed the game is played on the 32 dark fields of the chess board only.

There is no capturing by jumping and no stacking of checkers. Neither by jumping the opponent as in Checkers nor by moving onto its field replacing the opponent.

Fox wins by reaching the other side of the board (8th row where hounds started their hunt).
Hounds win by blocking the fox such that it cannot move anymore (when fox has no legal move left).

If moving perfect then hounds will win.

I have 2 playing pieces for this game with (remixed) dogs heads, even though when I was growing up I plaid this with chess pawns. Enjoy.

description.text:
I'm very new to printing and modelling but I saw the Unicorn light switch cover plate by MikeMasek and thought my girls would go bonkers for it. Only issue was that it wouldn't fit on my Monoprice Select Mini. So, I hacked this one together and probably made all kinds design mistakes but it worked and the girls love it. If you'd like to tell me all the things that could be improved, I'm all ears and eager to learn.

If you decide to print this on a MP Select Mini, be advised...I changed my print bed x and y dimensions to 127 to make this work. On one pass while printing the raft I did hear it bump against its hard limit so if you can make it work with everything set to 126 mm you might be better off. Needless, this print makes for a very full print bed on the MPSM.

I printed with white PLA and it turned out pretty well. On the next one, I'll probably increase the outer layer a bit because it is a little translucent in some light. It is also 1 or 2mm smaller in diameter than the cover that was on there but it still covers well and looks good. Last thing is that the screws won't sit flush unless you dremel them out a bit...could be easily fixed in the model. If I do another version, I'll fix this in the model.

Thanks! Enjoy!

description.text:
This is based on the original thing by ChaosCoreTech and the subsequent remix by Cyphn.

I was not quite satisfied with the stability of the core/logo mechanisms in either the original or remix and decided to rework the model so that it is far more stable and less prone to snapping/breaking.

I designed a snapping mechanism so that the logos stay secure and oriented properly. The cap pieces snap easily into each other and are rather easily removed as well. You can see my cross section analysis to get an idea of what the snapping mechanism looks like.

You can also view this explosion animation to see how it is assembled.

In addition to the original open/batarang function, the blade also folds down about half way so it can be used in a slashing or stabbing motion with a comfortable grip.

The tolerances on the core/wings is purposefully very tight so that the wings to do not move loosely. It will be a very tight fit, but it fits (I've printed out like 8 of them). If you are unsatisfied with how tight they are, some light sanding will do the trick.

I re-used Cyphn's limiting wall on the rear cap piece so the blade is limited in how far it can be opened. Admittedly, this piece is easy to snap/break in my design, but I am not likely to revisit this part of the design as I have ended up preferring it without this nub anyway (since the tolerances are so tight, the blade stays where you set it). If you also prefer it this way, simply snap it off, haha.

Overall, I feel like this design incorporates the best ideas from both the things it was inspired from and provides a very stable/strong core/cap mechanism to boot.

Thanks so so so so so much to ChaosCoreTech for making his F360 files available for use. It saved me quite a lot of time. :)

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

You can print the caps with the logo facing down without supports. This gives the logo background a pretty interesting texture if your bridging is decent. If you want to print it with the logos facing up, you'll need support.

Support is recommended for the blades/wings unless you are printing at a .15 or .1 layer height, where you might be able to get away with no supports, but I dunno.

The blades are the same, but I included them as left and right just for the hell of it.

comments.author: AnaErwin

description.text:
Marko Tadros had the very clever idea to create an inverse beveled circle to make releasing his prints easily. This is possible because Moonray S and other SLA printers can print at very steep overhang angles. You can simply drop this at the edge of your support raft, and your spatula will pop the print right off.

His original design is posted here
https://www.365digitaldentistry.com/product-page/er-easy-release-3d-printing-botton

My feeling is that having a polygon instead of a round circle will give you more purchase with your prying tool and result in an even easier removal. But the only way to know is to release this into the wild and let everyone experiment!

So I give you my take on the ER buttons. I've included 3, 5, 6, 7 and completely round version. My rendition has the same release angle, but a hollow beveled top so you can see it easier and also save a few drops of resin.

Try them out on your next rafted print and let me know how you like them!

title: Easy Remove Pet Cage Bowl(small animal)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My Daughter-in-law wanted a set of food/water bowls for her sugar glider(Jinx) that were easy to remove from the cage but secured to the wire grid of the cage.

The clips on the rear of the holder are spaced and sized to fit her existing cage(i.e. the separation fits the vertical spacing of the bars and the grippers are sized to fit the wire gauge).
You can also try to resize it to fit individual needs.
I have also included a design without the grippers for different cages. Simply use craft wire or twist-ties to attach it to the grid. You could also attach it with screws to a wooden cage.

My first design was the square one.
I designed the polygonal one purely for aesthetics.

The square one holds a greater volume but may be harder to clean.

The tab/slot make it secure(so it doesn't end up spilled all over the cage).

The small nub on the end of the holder arm doesn't seem to want to print properly on my printer, but it isn't necessary.

The bowls don't require any support.
the holders are oriented to make it easier to remove support(but with a minor amount of waste).
I suggest printing the water dish in solid mode since I have experienced leakage due to porosity of the structure on some items I've printed in the past(i.e. planter pots).

I hope these are useful for those of us that love and enjoy our furry family members.

Please let me know what you think.

Enjoy, and remember, keep creating!

description.text: An 'angry' grille I made for my scx10 Jeep. Requires cutting part of the body for the angles on the sides, works well if you have 2.2s with a stretched wheelbase. I used 4 screws in the slots for the holes to mount it, use flat heads with black faces and you can hardly tell that they are there. I printed the grille in black and mesh backing in white. The mesh part fits between the grille and the body with tape to hold it. To print the mesh in a criss-cross pattern insert both files (1 and 2) into a gcode software and overlap them so they create an x-pattern mesh. Enjoy!

This is an 8mm cine develoment tank reel. How many feet you ask? I don't really know, as much as will fit, somewhere between 50' and 100', one hopes. I am constrained by printbed size, so I am trying to fit as much as possible into a 220mm bed. This is a work in progress, I have not even printed one yet. There is precious little support for cine processing around that I have found and these reels and tanks tend to skew expensive on sites like ebay, and even then you usually have to order them from Siberia (I am in the US) and they are liable to come broken. I designed this last year and forgot about it until I saw another user was working on the same thing. (Shoutout to Haize whose own project reminded me that I was working on this!) Their project is here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2565363

I will also try to design a working tank with a real light trap to go with this if anyone finds this useful.

Yeah...
So, you cram two rows of six 18650 cells stacked on top of each other, nickel tabbed.

You get one of these. You can shop from them on amazon or alibaba or ali express or where you please. They seem to be mass produced in China. But, this product is the form factor for this 3D print: https://www.amazon.com/Dual-USB-Power-Bank-Board/dp/B06WVMY2YW?SubscriptionId=AKIAILSHYYTFIVPWUY6Q&tag=duckduckgo-ffsb-20&linkCode=xm2&camp=2025&creative=165953&creativeASIN=B06WVMY2YW

Slap the circuit in there and solder the B+ on the circuit board to the battery's plus and the B- on the board to the battery's anode, with some leads.

If you like things not to rattle around, hot glue the board in there. Hot glue the case shut.

author: Fred003

title: CR 10 Y Axis Linear Rail Bracket

description.text: This bracket converts the y axis 6 wheel mount system to two linear rails to improve stability and create a smoother print.

Instructions

In addition to the stock hardware, you will need the following additional hardware:

  • 2 x 500mm linear rails with 2 MGN9C mounting blocks per rail https://goo.gl/1q6nQf
  • 4 x M3 Sliding T nuts https://goo.gl/PYDcSn
  • 4 x M3 x 6mm hex socket head screws https://goo.gl/MtBYNq
  • 16 x M3 x 12mm hex socket head screws https://goo.gl/MtBYNq

  1. Completely disassemble the build plate and y axis components, but do not remove the 2040 extrusion. The y axis belt doesn't need to be completely removed from the extrusion or from the mount plate, but it will at least need to be loosened and the mount plate moved out of the way. To do this, loosen the tension bracket and remove its center guide bearing.

  2. Install linear rails on either side of the center 2040 extrusion and loosely secure each end with 6mm screws and T nuts. Do not tighten, allow them to slide freely.

  3. Position the bracket over the rail mounting blocks and secure with 12mm screws. Holes may need to be drilled with 1/8 drill bit if not exactly aligned. Loosely fit all screws and then tighten in alternating pattern to ensure everything is as straight as possible.

  4. Using the original bolts and nuts from the old 6 wheel assembly, mount the y axis plate to the bracket, nuts facing up.

  5. Reassemble tension bracket and guide bearing and properly tension belt.

  6. Manually move y axis plate all the way to one end, visually center the bracket over the extrusion, then tighten the bolts securing the linear rails on that side. Then move the plate all the way to the other end, allowing the rails to center themselves, and secure the other side. This ensures the rails are parallel to each other and can freely move back and forth. If there is any uneven resistance while manually sliding, you may not have secured the bracket to the rail mounts completely straight. Disassemble as necessary and loosen/tighten mounting block screws until straight.

  7. While manually sliding y axis plate back and forth, visually ensure the bracket does not touch the 2040 extrusion. If it does, loosen bolts securing linear rails to frame and repeat step 6.

  8. Reassemble build plate springs/screws/heat plate/etc.. and use printer as normal. Bed will be slightly lower than before, so calibration will be necessary. If needed, use metal washers between bracket and y axis plate to provide more height, but ensure everything is tight or plate may wobble.

It is recommended linear rails be oiled frequently to ensure their longevity and least amount of friction. 3 in 1 oil recommended, but can also use liquid wrench. DO NOT USE WD40. As it is a solvent, it will quickly evaporate and gum up the bearings.

comments.text: Sorry for the delay.  Does make a bit more noise, but nothing considerable or annoying.  The main improvement over the V wheels is that these don't loosen or wear over time, and because they are a dual rail system and not just a single center mount, you eliminate the side to side wobble that causes issues with print quality.  Only thing I'd do in the future would be to look for wider rails, so that they're even more stable, but this is leaps and bounds better than the V wheels in my opinion.

author: admodesi

description.text:
I wanted to make a collet tray for my ER20 collets, so I drew these collet models to help me do it. I found that the measurements and standards vary a bit, so I actually came up with 3 different models. The inch model is based on the drawing I found on the MariTool website, the metric model is based on the drawing I found on AliExpress, and the measured model is based on my own caliper work with the set of DrillPro collets that I ordered from BangGood. All 3 models are based on the same 30deg nose and 8deg tail, because that specific was the same in both drawings (and I don't have an accurate way to measure that myself).

All three are slightly different, but the collets that I measured appear to be closer to the 'inch' drawing's dimensions. Still, I figured that I'd include all 3 in case you have a different experience.

My collets from BangGood also seem to all have a 10mm ID on the back side, so that's the size of the through hole that I added to these models. Your mileage may vary.

Inches: https://www.maritool.com/Collets-ER-Collets-ER20-Collets/c21_56_62/index.html
Metric: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/ER25-collets-4mm/523793862.html
Measured: https://www.banggood.com/13pcs-1-13mm-ER20-CNC-Carving-Machine-Milling-Chuck-Collets-p-957223.html?cur_warehouse=CN

description.text:
The cryptex was a graduation gift for the seniors on my robotics team (FRC Team 1351 - TKO) We wrote thank-you notes and well wishes on little pieces of paper and stuffed them into the cryptex to be given to the seniors during our end-of-the-year banquet night. The rings that are currently available to print were intended to spell out 1-3-5-1 as the code, but that can be customized with the placement of the rings.

Enjoy! :)

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.35 mm

Infill:

5%-15% (personal preference)

Notes:

The model was made in inches, so for most printing applications it'll have to be scaled up by 25.4. I primarily printed in PLA but I'm sure it'll work just as well with other materials.

Printing time for each part alone is about 1 hour. In total, it's somewhere around 4-8 hours to print everything.

I designed the top assembly in two pieces to remove the need for supports, and separated the bottom assembly in order to keep the rings in one place with superglue.

Instructions
  1. Print:
    4 X Rings (Any number)
    1 X Top (Body)
    1 X Top (Lid)
    1 X Bottom (Base)
    1 X Bottom (Body)
  2. Put the 4 rings on the bottom base, and superglue the bottom base to the bottom body.
  3. Superglue the top base to the top lid.
  4. Wait for the assemblies to dry. I'd recommend using a rubber band to keep the parts in position.
  5. Test out your new cryptex! Line up the correct code with the nubbin at the base of the robot face to unlock the cryptex.

This is a remix of the excellent original by RTicknor at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1619508. All credit for the model goes to him! I'm just sharing the way I played with it to fit my needs (my son is plane-crazy, so simplified printing is a must).
Changes:

  • Down-scaled to print on a single 200x200x180mm print bed. Now it's 1:200 scale.
  • Joined several parts to minimize gluing
  • Split wings and engines so they can print without supports
  • Added a new stand with the aircraft's name.

There are some significant overhangs needed to print the tail. As usual with overhangs, use finer Z resolution (0.15mm or thinner) and increase the number of walls (I used 4). The upside is you don't need any infill.

Assembled easily with Barge cement. I plan to sand and paint it, and will update image when done.

If you'd like to play with my edits, go right ahead:

Originally produced by Games Workshop for their 6mm scale table top wargame, Epic. They have since abandoned all support for their game, so I modeled this in Autodesk Inventor for any avid wargamers.

Epic is being re-released as Adeptus Titanicus some time in the near future, though reports indicate it will initially be titans only. Apparently it will be 8mm scale instead of 6mm, so I suggest that anyone wanting to print this for AT gaming should upscale it by 133%.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in PLA as a concept, and is holding up nicely. When I progress to harder materials I may update the design.

description.text:
Howdy, Pilots! I created an antenna mount to go on my Martian II frame and thought I would share.

My reasons for creating this mount were:

1) To not have my SMA/antenna fouling on the top plate of my martian, when this bracket is mounted at the top of the standoffs (as pictured). The other design I found that fit these fatter standoffs, projected the antenna/SMA up at a 45 degree angle, which fouled the nut and washers on the top plate.
2) To have a low profile antenna mount capable of mounting on wider-than-stock 6mm standoffs.

For my frame build I used orange 6mm diameter, 30mm tall standoffs, as pictured. These are slightly wider than the stock purple Martian and Alien standoffs and can be picked up in a variety of colours from Banggood.
The antenna mounting hole is 6.35mm in diameter and is a snug fit for the SMA extension cable I used. It will also fit most VTx's directly should you not want to use an extension.
The mount projects the antenna/SMA connector out the back of the quad, parallel with the top and bottom plates. A flexible RH/LHCP antenna is advised to achieve proper signal projection.

Printer:

Cocoon Create Touch

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100

Notes:

Printed in PLA as a concept, and is holding up nicely. When I progress to harder materials I may update the design.

Tips for fitting:
1) Depending on your printer's accuracy, some filing may be necessary to fit the SMA/Antenna connector to the bracket.
2) Use a soldering iron to heat-fit the bracket to your standoffs. Incrementally begin heating each standoff in 10sec cycles for about 40 seconds total. This heat will transfer to the bracket, soften the material and sensually slide down the standoff to the desired position. I printed mine in PLA and once cooled, it hardened and shrunk back down to a tight fit on the standoff knurling.
3) If mounting your VTx directly to the bracket, backup the bracket with a cable tie snuggly around the VTx and top plate. This should help with crash stress relief.

title: Pawn-ish (First ever model) Made in Spacedraw

description.text:
Hi folks,

So this is my first ever model. I've only just come over to the dark side and I'm loving what I'm seeing. The things that you people are designing and printing blow my mind! Please don't stop because you are an inspiration to the rest of us.

I've been laid up for a while now and have been looking for something to fill my time with, I think I've found it lol I have a Prusa i3 mk2 on order and can't wait for it to turn up.

So the model well like I've said it's my first go at making something. Now don't get me wrong I've messed about with the software trying out the different tools, but this is the first time I've put it all together into one model.

Im using Spacedraw because I don't own a pc or laptop, I only have my Samsung Galaxy Tab S2, so Spacedraw it is. I know that amazing models can be made with the software! I've seen some of the results, so I've got a lot of work to do learning the software. The problem I've got at the mo is I've got buy the key to increase my save ability, as soon as i do that i know things will improve.

Well thanks for reading this rubbish and hopefully I'll be posting more asap. Please give me constructive criticism, I would welcome it all.

Thanks folks!

Tim

description.text: I updated my beltless clip. This version has a narrower openinng. The version with the wider opening came off too easily Before you make this check out the write-up for earlier versaion "Beltless Clip".

Realizing that 3 or 4 of my 5 power sockets on my desk were used by 5V USB adapters, I decided to replace them all with a USB power distributor. The part is designed to fit 5 of these: https://www.tme.eu/gb/details/mx-48408-0003/usb-ieee1394-connectors/molex/48408-0003/ with a little bit of wiggle room to spare.

The part is designed in FreeCad (0.17), source file available.

The rim is designed to allow top placement (with adhesive tape or similar) in any place you can cut out a bottom / pocket for.

After printing, you just need to insert the USB jacks inside, and solder wires for 5V and GND (they are the leftmost and rightmost pins on the line with four pins), then hook them up to a 5V supply. I used a 5V, 10amp power source.

title: Z-Vice Turntable
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I have purchased a second hand Z-Vice (they don't seem to make these anymore), and it did not come with several of the accessories.

This is a turntable (plus additional washer) for the Z-Vice. It should enable a few degrees more movement than the original Z-vice turn table, although it won't be as strong as an original alloy one.

Below is a YouTube link to the Z-vice so you get an idea what I'm on about (hope I'm allowed to post links here).

This is a work in progress, as I might alter the model and reduce the amount of pla used, by removing block material and just adding ribs to stiffen the part, or even make it a bit bigger once I've tried this out.

Using cura recommended settings (for a CR10) says 140g and about 9 hour print with 20% infill...

title: CR-10 / Tronxy Mittens Cooler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Let's keep it cool!

My take on a better cooler for the CR-10 Tronxy X1/3 type hotend. The stock CR-10 set up can cool the heater block too much if you don't have it wrapped. The parts doesn't cool all sides well. My Tronxy X3 didn't have a parts cooler and the heater block couldn't get temps over 205C.

I tried a couple other popular coolers but did not fit my original parts blower or just not that efficient.

So the Mittens Cooler evolved. Printed in PETG, it weighs 12 grams. Has a bit fo a twist for a little vortex of air.

Needs a few things: a 5015 blower/fan, a few screws, a bit of rewiring, and a bit of tenacity.

Reported to work with the Tevo Tornado now.

WARNING: It works for me. Your results may vary wildly.

I've gone through dozens and dozens of printed revisions to get to this version.

If you find this useful and want to encourage my insanity, buy a cup of coffee for me, a bag of coffee, or you pick the value. Thanks!

Please note, this is not compatible with the auto-leveling sensor. Send me one and I'll try to make one fit.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed with a 10mm brim. My CR-10 took about 2 hours to print.
2 perimeters/shells, 5 top and 4 bottom layers.

I printed in PLA to get started then switch to better temperature-resistance PETG.

Has a built-in support piece (square patch) that should snap out easily. If not, you may have a bit of over-extrusion.

Clean up

Break out the square support. Should snap out, but it it needs some coaxing, carefully use a hobby knife. Trim away the brim and any stray printed strands. Check the parts blower outlets and clean up as needed.

WARNING: Use at your own risk. I've tested this best I can at this time and works great for me. Your results may vary greatly.

Gather parts
  • existing 40mm fan
  • M3x12 or possible 10s (2-4) -- for mounting fan to Mittens Cooler (should be able to reuse existing screws)
  • 5015 blower/fan (needs to be wired--splice and solder or add a connector)
  • M3x8 screw -- for holding 5015 fan/blower
  • M3x16 screw (2) -- for attaching Mitten Cooler and block to mount (should be able to reuse existing screws
Disassembly
  • Disassemble the hot end removing the housing screws and the fan mounting screws.
  • Wire in the new 5015 fan.blower paying attention to red and black wiring.
  • Save the screws since some can be reused.
Assembly

The screws should thread themselves into the Mitten Cooler. If they are super tight, you may be over-extruding. Ream the holes bit and try fitting the screws again.

  • make sure the printer is off
  • snap the hot end in the back of the Mitten Cooler with the heater wiring to the left
  • line up the mounting holes to the top two holes on the finned cooling block
  • push through the M3x16 screws
  • check to make sure the parts cooling outlets are above the nozzle opening
  • carefully line up to the mount
  • tighten screws -- if there is an resistance, make sure the screws are aligned properly
  • insert the 5015 fan/blower
  • insert the Mx8 screw in the top hole
  • tighten screw to snuggle hold the 5015 fan/blower
  • screw in the 40mm fan using M3x12/16. Can get by with just two screws. Snug but not too tight or you could warp the fan adding more noise
  • check clearance on everything and the give it a go

These are the 3D printed parts I designed to convert a Zervo Dry Food Dispenser into an automatic pet feeder.

The feeder is powered by a Raspberry Pi, Geared Motor, and Relay Board. It is programmed to dispense food three times a day and send a picture via email every time it dispenses the food.

More info on this project can be found at THIS imgur link.

Printing Notes

The food Chute is printed in 3 pieces for ease of printing and then glued together. The
Pet_Feeder_Chute_Ring is glued to the Pet_Feeder_Chute_Top only at the center/rear of the Ring so the sides can be squeezed together to be inserted into the bottom of the dispenser hopper.

The mount for the internal electronics is also printed in 2 pieces for ease of printing and it is also glued together.

I have not tested the coupler for the motor but it should work.

description.text:
A common Problem on those old Home Computers is electronics dying.

I had a Problem with my Commodore 128 where one of the latching Keys on the
Keyboard stopped working. It is nearly impossible to get a working new one so
i decided to Design a Adapter.

It is designed to fit those cheap Chinese latching 8x8mm Switches you could get
at Amazon and other sources.

https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00SFRBLG2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The bigger Part with the 8x8 hole is for using in the Keyboard, the two small parts
are the adapters for the key to switch.

Just drop the Switch in the 8x8 hole and mount the Key using the proper adapter. Then
insert the replacement in your Keyboard an adjust Key heigth.

If the height is ok, glue the Switch to the Large Adapter to stop it from going further down.

description.text:
Still a work in progress as I figure out thickness and look into putting textures on the hexes. Can be printed at 50% infill, at around 8 hours.

The hexes are a little big for Battletech, I'm working on a separate project for them that will be up soon in-development. Going to rename this files as well, to make it more explicit that they're for Shadespire.

Hex Board 1.1a and 1.1b: Separate pieces of one of the standard Shadespire boards, with the smashed statue head.
Hex Board 1.2a and 1.2b: Flip side of the boards composing 1.1a/b. They have 3 blocked hexes, which are flat, allowing you to put terrain or other hexes in.
Hex Board 2.1a and 2.1b : Separate pieces of a standard Shadespire board, with the crypts.
Hex Board 2.2a and 2.2b: Separate pieces of the Shadespire board with 1-2 hex blocked area and 1 1-hex blocked area.

Simple parametric design to hold wire to wind a toroid easily.

The end cutouts are inset the same as the width, so the default version is 30mm long and 5mm wide (for a 6mm toroid hole) so wire held for one complete wrap is
2(L-(W2)) = 2 (30-10) = 40mm wire per wrap.
One turn on my particular Toroid is 2 (5.33mm + 2.33mm) = approx 16mm rounded up
So to wrap 100 turns I need 1600mm or 40 turns on the spool.
Now simplified so you just enter how much wire you want to hold for one COMPLETE turn on the spool, the spool thickness is taken into account as well.

My first customizer job, to see how it works..

edit:seems the customizer is broken, so you need to have openscad (Get it anyway!)
https://www.thingiverse.com/groups/thingiverse/forums/site-issues-and-feedback/topic:26898

I will upload some different sizes anyway.

done, format is wire_length_per_turn,spool_width,spool_thickness
So for 1600mm of wire (100 turns) on my 6mm ID toroid, I need the 50_5_1 version, and do 32 turns of wire on it, or the 100_5_2 version and do 16 turns, my wire is thin so the short version will be fine.

Photos show 32 wraps on the spool for 1.6m wire and then what remains after wrapping 100 turns.

description.text:
If you have an bastex SAE Hex wrench set like this one on Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B076KNFMHQ/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Then you've probably realized it's a pain in the but to get the wrench through both holes in the rack when it's facing you as you can't see the second set of holes. This is a guide which funnels each wrench from the top hole to the bottom. Works great for the set I made it for, But there seem to be a lot of other models that are similar, so I included a 1.5mm hole test you can use to see if your rack fits, and if not to help calibrate for your rack. I've included the SketchUp file to help with this process.

description.text:
I set out to make a calibration tool to test for square so I made 240x240.stl. The estimated time was 2 hours so I moved these 4 cubes to the edge and centered with the points on the square. It only takes 10 minutes and is easier to measure with 2 parallel flat spots instead of points.

The idea is (once you get your corner pulley mounts and motor mounts installed) to print this out, measure the distances and input that into this skew correction program. Then print out 2 skew corrected Y gantry brackets. This will only work if your machine is square to begin with. If not there is another step involved. Look at AdjustableX Y Gantry for12mmpulleys.scad (link below)and read the description. With these two fixes your machine can print perfectly even if it's not square.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2733592

This should fix any problem and make your machine more accurate. Here's a tip.... adjust the calibration file for skew after taking your measurements and if you did it right it should print out perfectly and have the same measurement. Keep playing with the angle value generated by the program until its right.

Here's a link to the program called Gskew bundled with some other useful CNC geared utilities. (If you're into that sorta thing :) Read the accompanying PDF.

http://pilotpage.monosock.org/fileadmin/files/Gsuite_v1.4.rar

I've printed the stl file uploaded here and an stl file produced from the scad file. I use simplify 3d for slicing and got best results by making sure that "Apply bridging settings to perimeters" is enabled and the unsupported area threshold is set low enough to bridge the top of the cutouts.

UPDATE: realized that I had the wrong file uploaded for the Intact bottom version - just updated, sorry!
UPDATE 2: If you have your players descend into a crypt from the tomb entrance, I made some matching stairs for inside the crypt.

Just hit 300 followers over on EC3D Facebook Group, so in celebration I made this tomb, remixed from tons of other items on Thingiverse and lots of my own sculpting/design. These were built to fit stylistically with the ruins of Terrain4Print's Ulvheim buildings, and is very easy to print and paint!

The tomb comes in 2 varieties - In tact and ruined. The models are hollow inside to preserve filament but there is no internal design currently. Both parts print with no supports, and in the pictures I printed @ .16mm layer height in black PLA with 8% infill, primed with 80% coverage dark gray, then dry brushed lighter gray. I was in a rush to get these done - printing at .16mm still looks great, but if you do .12 you will most likely get more detail with the floral designs and writing.

VERY happy with the results - thanks to everyone who designed all the pieces I used, and hope this sees some cool usage on your tables - I know my players will love them!

If you like these items, check out the full set on Hero's Hoard, and follow EC3D on Facebook, where I give away premium model sets to a follower twice a month!

title: "Brake" for K8400 VERTEX Universal Spool Holder

description.text:
This is add-on to my Universal Spool Holder. As mentioned by Jaecko here

"... the holder is so smooth running that the spool uncoils a bit when the extruder yanks at the filament."

I had the same issue and even couple of failed prints because of this, so I ended-up designing this "brake" that fixed the problem.

Part1 is attached to the printer permanently. The rest is removable. I uploaded 2 versions of part2. Part2.stl is for the original Vertex, part2evo.stl is for VertexEvo with 3mm thick aluminium enforcement bars.

Part3 is designed to fit eSun and Shaxon 1kg filament spools. If you are using spools of different width - resize part3. Part3.sat file is attached.

You will need to glue a strip of rubber to the areas of part3 that touch the spool.

Three M3 x 12mm and one M3 x 16mm screws were used to put parts together.
Two M8 x 25mm screws and two M8 self-locking nuts serve as a ballast. If you want to use different type of ballast - redesign part5. Part5.sat file is also attached. The weight of ballast should be around 50 grams.

You will need to replace M5 screws to the longer ones to attach part1 to the side panel. With my VertexEvo I used M5 x 25mm screws. For the original Vertex - M5 x 20mm screws should work.
